tutorial.name: Importing data from IDA Pro
tutorial.description:
One of the first aspects of working with disassembled data is to get the disassembled data from IDA Pro into the BinNavi database.

In this tutorial you will learn
  • how to use IDA Pro as a data source for BinNavi

step.description:
This tutorial shows you how to use IDA Pro as a data source to get data into an existing MySQL database. To do this you will disassemble a test file in IDA Pro and tell BinNavi to convert the data from the created IDB file to the MySQL database. By the end of the tutorial, all disassembled data from the IDB file will be stored in the MySQL database and you can start working with the disassembled data.

Please click on the Next button to continue.

Even though you can use any IDB file in this tutorial it is recommended that you disassemble the file primes.exe which you can find in the tutorials subdirectory of your BinNavi installation.

Please disassemble this file now and save the disassembled data to an IDB file. When you are done close IDA Pro. This last step is very important because IDA Pro locks the IDB file as long as it is running and BinNavi can not import the data from the IDB file while the IDB file is locked.

Please click on the Next button to continue.

This tutorial requires an existing MySQL database configuration. If you do not yet have a database configured please create the database configuration now.

Once you have created the database, please click on the Next button to continue.

Now that the IDB file exists you can tell BinNavi to import the data from the IDB file into a database. You can use the following ways to start the import process:
  • Right-click the database in the Project Tree and click Import IDB File
  • Right-click the Modules node of a database in the Project Tree and click Import IDB File
  • Select the database in the Project Tree and click the Database / Import IDB File menu
  • Select the Modules folder in the Project Tree and click the Module / Import IDB File menu
Whichever way you choose, you will be asked for the location of your IDA Pro executable file (if you did configure that location previously) and the IDB file you want to import. The rest of the import process is handled automatically by BinNavi. If nothing goes wrong, you can find a new entry in the Modules node of the Project Tree. This new entry primes.exe contains all the disassembled data that was imported from the IDB file.

If you have not done so yet, you will also be asked to configure the location of your IDA Pro executable. In the same dialog you can install the exporters you want to use to get data from IDA Pro into BinNavi.
If the import process of the IDB file was successful you can click the Next button to continue. If something went wrong you can now try to import the IDB file again.

If the module import was successful a new node that represents the BinNavi module of the IDB file should have appeared in the Project Tree. If the import was not successful please try to find out what went wrong and try import the IDB file again.

In the final step of this tutorial we will load the BinNavi module so that you can see the data of the module. You can load a module using any of the following ways
  • Double-click on the primes.exe module node in the Project Tree
  • Right-click the primes.exe module node and click the Load Module menu
  • Select the primes.exe module node and click the Module / Load Module menu
Please open the module now to continue.

Now that the module is loaded you can see the functions of the module or other data of the module on the right-hand side of the main window when you select the module node or one of its children in the Project Tree.

You have reached the end of this tutorial. You are now familiar with the concept of modules and how to get data from IDA Pro into the database.

Please click on the Next button to finish this tutorial.
